title: Can a bankruptcy attorney reverse a chapter 7 filing in California after it has been discharged?
question: The bankruptcy attorney is a friend of one of my family members. He gave me a low down payment for my chapter 7 bankruptcy because I was unemployed. I promised to make payments. The bankruptcy was discharged in February 2012. I told him I would make a $100.00 payment every month until it is paid off because that is really all I can afford. Now they are threatening to reverse my chapter 7 if I don't give them all the money immediately. I told them I honestly don't have the money and would keep making the payments as long as they don't reverse the chapter 7. Can they really reverse it? Or just sue me? I don't know if it is an empty threat.
answers:
What your former attorney is doing is clearly wrongful. The attorney's pre-petition fees were discharged in your case, and the discharge injunction bars all attempts at collection of the fee. While a Chapter 7 case can be reopened and a discharge vacated to allow the case to be dismissed, doing so is highly unusual and you alone would have standing to seek the voluntary dismissal of your case. This might occur where a debtor came into a sizable amount of money more six months after the case was filed and wanted to pay his or her debts and erase the record of the bankruptcy for credit purposes. But attorneys cannot use such a threat to collect fees, discharged or not.

What your former attorney is doing is clearly a violation of the discharge injunction and may be punishable as a contempt of court, allowing you to recover damages, including attorney's fees you may incur in enforcing your discharge, and where the violation is egregious, you may be able to recover for emotional distress. In addition, your former attorney is violating the California Rules of Professional Conduct and may be subject to discipline. The State Bar Attorney Complaint Hotline is (800) 843-9053 or visit http://www.calbar.ca.gov/Attorneys/LawyerRegulation/FilingaComplaint.aspx. In addition, bankruptcy attorneys must be admitted to practice in the District in which they file cases and a complaint can be filed with the Bankruptcy Court, directed to the Clerk of the Court.

I am shocked that any bankruptcy attorney would be willing to jeopardize his license to practice bankruptcy law by making such an outrageous claim.

I would write a short letter to the bankruptcy judge & include any documents you have from the attorney so that the court can investigate this matter. This is attorney misconduct.

Hope this perspective helps!

No, the discharge cannot be reversed for non-payment of attorneys fees. Not only is the attempt to collect probably a discharge or continuing stay violation, the threat to reverse your discharge is probably a violation of California State Bar ethics rules. The case which states that pre-petition fees are dischargeable debts is Hessinger & Assocs. v. United States Trustee (In re Biggar), 110 F.3d 685 (9th Cir. 1997).

Any debts that you had before the filing of the bankruptcy should have been listed as debts with the bankruptcy court. That includes attorney fees. Attorneys are SOL if they don't get paid upfront from CH 7 fees since they are unsecured debts.

This attorney who did this may have been a friend but most likely not a bankruptcy attorney.

This set of facts will be specific to your jurisdiction and how the court enforce the issue where you live.

First and foremost, a Debtor does not have an absolute right to dismiss a Chapter 7. Your Creditors or Trustee can object to dismissal of your case. More than likely, if you showed up to the hearing and explained the situation, your case would not be dismissed.

In Phoenix, Arizona, this has potential, but is not guaranteed to be a problem for you as a Debtor.

If your attorney prepared all of your paperwork prior to filing bankruptcy, then there will some difficulty enforcing the agreement. Covered services under the contract must be disclosed to the Court.

Once you are armed with this information, then you can know how to proceed.

You will need to speak with an attorney to know what this information means.

Anything you owed your attorney at the time of filing is discharged, and any attempt by the attorney to collect is a violation of the discharge injunction. Your attorney immediately had a conflict of interest when your case was filed. Your attorney was a creditor in your case AND had an obligation to work for a discharge of that obligation. Any attempt (or threat) to work against your interest is a violation of professional ethics, and you should file a complaint with the state bar.

If he wants to put the friendship with your family member on the line, he can make that friendship contingent upon the family member making good on the debt, but he cannot go after you or your discharge to collect it.

Sure, you can volunteer to pay, but your fresh start is not dependent upon your agreeing to pay debts that were discharged.

No, the cannot "reverse" a bankruptcy discharge for non-payment of attorney fees.

If your narrative is accurate, this scenario likely falls within what is considered a violation of a discharge injunction.

You should check your original fee-agreement with this law firm (you were provided with a fee-agreement, right?).

If your fee agreement was executed pre-petition (aka, before your bankruptcy case was filed), and if if described the services to be provided for you during your case, then this would very likely be included in your bankruptcy case as dischargeable debt. Even if not scheduled as a creditor, the law firm would be stuck with biting the bullet for not having collected from you all attorney fees pre-petition.

Unfortunately, it sounds as though the law firm really came through for you when you were in a tough spot - apparently the had given you a break and helping you to afford the case and their services.

Legally speaking, however, unless you had a separate agreement, post-petition, for legal services of the law firm, they may be stuck without being able to collect from you.

That said, I'm not sure too many attorneys would be willing to "help" you (again) with that sort of case after understanding the facts that you have described.

Best of luck

I have never heard of a debtor's attorney "reversing" his own client's bankruptcy discharge. Occasionally, you see a creditor's attorney reopen a debtor's case and bring action for nondischargeability or denial of discharge. Nonetheless, the attorney's fees you agreed to pay your attorney are likely not discharged in bankruptcy and you will have to pay them. Try to make a reasonable arrangement and pay them off.
